author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Goldman Sachs awards its C.E.O. a raise to $35 million after a record year.
description: David M. Solomon is now tied with James Gorman of Morgan Stanley as the highest-paid chief executives at major U.S. banks.
content: Goldman Sachs bumped up compensation for its chief executive, David M. Solomon, after the bank pulled in record profits last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Tito Matos, Virtuoso of a Puerto Rican Sound, Dies at 53
description: A lifelong champion of the plena genre, he helped rejuvenate it for a new generation both in Puerto Rico and in New York.
content: Tito Matos, a master percussionist, revered educator and lifelong champion of the Puerto Rican style of music known as plena, died on Jan. 18 in San Juan, P.R. He was 53.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Formidable Party Crasher in ‘a Great Rivalry’
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 29, 2022.
content: “Being very honest, for me is much more important to have the chance to play tennis than win the 21, no?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: This is the fourth storm to hit the East Coast this month.
description: This weekend’s snow comes after a series of storms, including one that shut down Interstate 95 in Virginia for more than a day.
content: This weekend’s snowstorm is the fourth one that some parts of the East Coast have experienced in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Joni Mitchell Plans to Follow Neil Young Off Spotify, Citing ‘Lies’
description: “Irresponsible people are spreading lies that are costing people their lives,” she wrote after the site was accused of spreading vaccine misinformation.
content: Joni Mitchell said Friday that she would remove her music from Spotify, joining Neil Young in his protest against the streaming service over its role in giving a platform to Covid-19 vaccine misinformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: As Storms Intensify, the Job of TV Weather Person Gets More Serious
description: Once considered comic relief to anchors, television meteorologists are making it clear to viewers that they are covering a crisis in real time.
content: After the remains of Hurricane Ida dumped historic levels of rain in the Northeast last year, ABC News’s chief meteorologist, Ginger Zee, stood in front of a collapsed bridge in New Jersey and gave viewers of “Good Morning America” a clear warning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Harbath
title: I Worked at Facebook. It’s Not Ready for This Year’s Election Wave.
description: Facebook has taken steps to combat electoral interference in the U.S. It needs to do the same in other countries.
content: The world is not ready for the coming electoral tsunami. Neither is Facebook. With so many elections on the horizon — France, Kenya, Australia, Brazil, the Philippines and the United States will hold elections this year — the conversation now should focus on how Facebook is preparing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Covid-19 complicates preparations for the East Coast’s snowstorm.
description: The storm’s intensity could further strain staffing stretched by the Omicron variant. Some officials were considering hiring crews from outside the region.
content: As officials across the Northeast geared up on Friday to face high winds and blizzard conditions, work force shortages caused by Covid-19 complicated their efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: American Woman Accused of Prominent Role in Islamic State
description: Prosecutors said Allison Fluke-Ekren, a former teacher from Kansas, provided military training to women and young girls in Syria.
content: The F.B.I. has arrested an American woman who federal prosecutors said had risen through the ranks of the Islamic State in Syria to become a battalion commander, training women and children to use assault rifles and suicide belts, the Justice Department disclosed on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Is It OK to Watch the Winter Games? A Former Olympian Weighs In.
description: This year’s Winter Olympics come in the midst of widespread human rights abuses in China and a low point in Canada’s relations with the country.
content: By this time next week, the Winter Olympics will be well underway in Beijing. Like the Summer Olympics in Tokyo last year, the global gathering of athletes will occur during a global pandemic. But China’s first experience hosting the Winter Games comes when Canada’s relationship with the country is at a low amid an array of troubling human rights issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: It’s Lunar New Year. Get Ready for Some Fruit.
description: Oranges. Apples. Pomelos. Eating or giving fruit is a beloved Lunar New Year tradition in many Asian cultures, expressing love and thought to bring good luck.
content: In the days leading up to the Lunar New Year, Daphne Wu would wait for a pomelo to ripen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Esteban Torres, Congressional Advocate for Latinos, Dies at 91
description: A California Democrat who for a time served as chairman of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, he dedicated himself to fighting poverty.
content: Esteban Torres, an eight-term Democratic member of Congress from California who was dedicated to fighting poverty and who served for a time as chairman of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, died on Tuesday. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Will a Mask Debate Split Blue States?
description: The growing normalcy divide within liberal America.
content: The line between zealous Covid precautions and a mask-optional existence does not run simply between red and blue America, between areas that voted for Joe Biden and those that voted for Donald Trump. As Park MacDougald pointed out in a recent essay for the online magazine UnHerd, if you’re a New York City resident, you can experience two completely different realities just by traveling the short distance from the posher parts of Brooklyn to where he lives in Queens — passing from a world of ubiquitous N95s and careful checking of vaccine cards to a world where masking is maybe a 50 percent proposition and, outside of hipster establishments, the vaccine-pass rules are “almost totally unenforced.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italian Lawmakers Re-Elect Sergio Mattarella as President, Preserving Status Quo
description: Mr. Mattarella has presided over a chaotic seven years in which the country swung wildly from the left to the right, acting as the guardrails of Italy’s democracy.
content: ROME — After noxious and chaotic back-room negotiations, Italian lawmakers on Saturday re-elected the country’s current president, Sergio Mattarella , keeping the status quo, avoiding early elections and prolonging Italy’s current period of stability under Prime Minister Mario Draghi, who himself had coveted the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Facing a Ban, a School District Fights to Keep ‘Indian’ Nickname
description: Residents in a divided predominantly white town in upstate New York are fighting a state ruling to remove the Native American mascot.
content: Cory and Sarah McMillan of Cambridge, N.Y., recoiled when their 6-year-old daughter came home from her first-grade class one day and mentioned that she and her friend were playing “like animals” in a game they called “Savages.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Joe Biden and Peter Doocy Is the Rivalry Everyone Can Love
description: A notably unscripted exchange between President Biden and a Fox News correspondent went viral — and turned into what these days counts as a heartwarming civic moment.
content: At first blush, the instantly viral hot-mic incident at the White House on Monday, in which President Biden called a Fox News reporter “a stupid son of a bitch” on live television, presented a grim object lesson about today’s political-media complex: When vulgarity happens, everybody wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: As Covid Shots for Kids Stall, Appeals Are Aimed at Wary Parents
description: Getting more young school-age children vaccinated is crucial for ending the pandemic, public health officials say, and many are focusing on that group.
content: For weeks, the school principal had been imploring Kemika Cosey: Would she please allow her children, 7 and 11, to get Covid shots?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Cookbooks Overboard? A Shipping Accident Delays Two Major Releases.
description: Thousands of copies of two highly anticipated cookbooks may have gone into the Atlantic Ocean in their containers, their authors say.
content: Were you looking forward to making a fried bologna sandwich loaded with crisp vinegar-brined potato chips?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam and Blake Hounshell
title: What Mattered This Week
description: Democrats’ not-so-terrible news, the limits of Trump’s power and the allure of ’24.
content: President Biden got some rare good news this week, with Justice Stephen Breyer announcing his retirement from the Supreme Court and economic data showing rising wages and booming G.D.P. growth. And while inflation is still rising fast, a few new polls suggest that Biden’s slump might not doom Democrats’ chances of hanging onto the Senate after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: ISIS, Thriving in Unstable Places, Proves It’s Still a Threat
description: The Islamic State may no longer be able to control territory, but it has shown in Syria and Iraq that it can still pull off opportunistic military operations.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — One week after Islamic State fighters attacked a prison in northeastern Syria, where they have held out despite a heavy assault by a Kurdish-led militia backed by the United States, the terrorist organization published its version of what had gone down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson and Christina Jewett
title: When Omicron Isn’t So Mild
description: For those with underlying medical conditions, the latest pandemic wave has still posed a threat.
content: Regina Perez, 57, had never been hospitalized for her lifelong asthma condition until she came down with Covid this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Area of Recession
description: Andrew Ries and Caitlin Reid team up on a fast-moving Saturday challenge.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today we have a collaboration between two gem constructors who teamed up once before, in 2020, on another dazzler. Caitlin Reid and Andrew Ries are regular weekend contributors, and both are very funny. This grid isn’t madcap, but there are a lot of clever touches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Giants Hire Brian Daboll as Coach
description: Daboll had been the Bills’ offensive coordinator under Joe Schoen, whom the Giants hired as G.M. earlier this week after his tenure in Buffalo.
content: The Giants chose Brian Daboll, the former Bills offensive coordinator, as their next head coach, the team announced on Friday evening. Daboll will join his Buffalo colleague Joe Schoen, who earlier this week was announced as the Giants’ new general manager, in trying to match the success the Bills have had over a span in which the Giants have cratered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: As Russian Troops Mass in Belarus, a Ukraine Border Is Largely Undefended
description: From the border, it’s a fast 140 miles down a newly paved highway to Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, but only a few troops stand guard.
content: NOVI YARYLOVYCHI BORDER CROSSING, Ukraine — On the other side of this border in northern Ukraine, not visible through the thick pine and birch forests that crowd the E-95 highway but noticeable to passing truckers, a force is gathering in Belarus more potent than anything seen in the country since the fall of the Soviet Union, officials and military analysts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Heather MacLean on Returning to Racing After the Olympics
description: For many 2020 Olympians, the return to competition comes after an inevitable post-Olympic question: What’s next?
content: On a warm morning in early August, Heather MacLean laced up her sneakers and did what she usually does: She went for a run. Her time at the Tokyo Olympics was winding down after she had fallen short of qualifying for the final of the women’s 1,500 meters, and as she began to jog, she found herself coping with that hard reality — all the way down to her toes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Slavery Was About Profit
description: It lasted so long because there was money to be made.
content: I spent most of this month working on a long piece on using data to understand the trans-Atlantic slave trade. It is on the cover of the Sunday Review this week, if you want to check it out. One of the parts we had to trim for space was a paragraph on the domestic trade within the United States. A significant part of the slave system, the domestic trade relied on the sale of “surplus” slaves from the states of the Upper South down to New Orleans and beyond. Here’s what I wrote:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: In North Carolina, a Pitched Battle Over Gerrymanders and Justices
description: A fight over who is fit to hear a redistricting case highlights what experts say is the growing influence of ideology and money over state supreme courts nationwide.
content: It is the state that put the hyper in partisan politics, setting the blunt-force standard for battles over voting rights and gerrymanders that are now fracturing states nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: Canadian Trucker Convoy Descends on Ottawa to Protest Vaccine Mandates
description: The “Freedom Convoy” had driven across Canada to reach the capital. The demonstrations on Saturday were raucous but largely peaceful.
content: OTTAWA — Thousands of protesters gathered in front of Canada’s Parliament on Saturday in a raucous demonstration, which began as a movement by truckers to challenge a government vaccination mandate but spread to include a wide array of antigovernment grievances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
title: In India’s Militarized Regions, Calls for Ending Impunity
description: A deadly mistaken ambush by soldiers seeking rebels in the country’s northeast has renewed attention on a special powers act that residents say perpetuates fear and harassment.
content: OTING, India — Technically, there is no war anymore in Nagaland, but the peace does not feel certain, either. What the remote northeastern Indian state has is a lot of soldiers, keeping a heavy hand and provoking a rising anger among residents who say change is long overdue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Millennial Nightlife Swanks Up
description: Jon Neidich opened Acme, a groundbreaking restaurant and trendy night spot in New York City. A decade later, the rising impresario has opened a piano bar.
content: One recent frigid evening, a procession of 30-somethings wearing peacoats and high heels beneath puffy layers pushed past a curtain and walked into the elegant red saloon of the Nines, a new piano bar in the NoHo neighborhood of Manhattan that aims to fashion itself as a downtown Bemelmans. A pianist played jazzy covers of David Bowie and Chaka Khan tunes for guests nestled in fancy banquettes. Everyone seemed to be sipping martinis served with sidecars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: What Does ‘a Desk for Working Parents’ Mean?
description: Baby steps.
content: A week ago, a tweet about a Virginia library that went out of its way to accommodate parents went viral. The tweet included a photo of a desk or carrel that had a built-in toddler-friendly sidecar, so that parents without child care who need to use the desk’s accompanying computer might have their kids occupied, distracted and comfortably contained for a few minutes, allowing them to focus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Viet Thanh Nguyen
title: My Young Mind Was Disturbed by a Book. It Changed My Life.
description: Books are not inert tools of pedagogy. They are mind-changing, world-changing.
content: When I was 12 or 13 years old, I was not prepared for the racism, the brutality or the sexual assault in Larry Heinemann’s 1974 novel, “Close Quarters.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Storm forces cancellation of thousands of flights on East Coast.
description: A powerful winter storm drove flight cancellations up to nearly 5,000 flights on Friday and Saturday in and out of the United States, according to FlightAware, a site that tracks flights and the airline industry.
content: A powerful winter storm drove flight cancellations up to nearly 5,000 flights on Friday and Saturday in and out of the United States, according to FlightAware, a site that tracks flights and the airline industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Putin Has Long Tried to Balance Europe. Now He’s Working to Reset It.
description: After years of trying to diplomatically divide and conquer, the Russian leader has seemingly decided to antagonize Europe as a whole in the current Ukraine crisis.
content: For much of his 22 years in high office, Vladimir V. Putin has worked to carefully balance Russia’s position in Europe. He ingratiated himself with some capitals as he bullied others, and sought economic integration as he lambasted European values.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Cloud of Supreme Court Confirmation Bitterness Hangs Over Coming Fight
description: The battles of the recent past will no doubt extend into the coming fight over President Biden’s choice to replace Justice Stephen G. Breyer.
content: WASHINGTON — It was a testament to the breakdown of the Senate’s judicial confirmation machinery that the first question posed by many this past week regarding an upcoming Supreme Court vacancy was whether Democrats could install a new justice entirely on their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Britannia, With Fewer Rules
description: What England’s push to get back to business as usual says about the national character.
content: Soccer in the United Kingdom is a celebration of the British at their most tribal. A fan of one team might live next door to a fan of another and if they don different shirts on game day, these neighbors will be steeped in different lore and howl for different outcomes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Ashleigh Barty Wins Australian Open Women’s Singles Title
description: The top-ranked Barty defeated an American, Danielle Collins, to become the first Australian to win the Grand Slam singles title there since 1978. “I’m so proud to be an Aussie,” she said.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The 44-year drought was over in Ashleigh Barty’s sunburned country. Barty, often inscrutable on a tennis court, had just finished letting her guard down with a full-flex howl of delight that could almost be heard above the roars in Rod Laver Arena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: U.S. Sanctions Aimed at Russia Could Take a Wide Toll
description: The boldest measures that President Biden is threatening to deter an invasion of Ukraine could roil the entire Russian economy — but also those of other nations.
content: WASHINGTON — The most punishing sanctions that U.S. officials have threatened to impose on Russia could cause severe inflation, a stock market crash and other forms of financial panic that would inflict pain on its people — from billionaires to government officials to middle-class families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Watch Your Step!
description: Ross Trudeau never lets us down, does he?
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Say what you will about the state of the world*, but in the little enclave inhabited by the Sunday Times crossword puzzle, 2022 is off to a banging good start. Today’s grid is a doozy: creative, seemingly chaotic, but intricate and precise in its execution. It’s also quite difficult, stuffed with trickery and built around a treacherous theme (with an infernal rebus!). It took me several passes through the grid to nail down just what was afoot, and a few more to fill in all my blank spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Water Runoff From Next Door Is Damaging My Property. What Can I Do?
description: When it comes to property disputes among neighbors, the best course is typically to open a dialogue. But first, assess the source and the extent of the damage.
content: Q: For 21 years, rain runoff from my neighbor’s roof has flowed downhill onto our property in Madison, N.J., where it floods our backyard patio and seeps into our basement, filling our sump pump (which runs most days) and soaking the basement walls, creating mold. The neighbor, a kind older woman, always seemed oblivious to the issue. She recently moved into an assisted-living facility and sold the house to one of her children. I’d like to approach the new owner about the issue, but I’m concerned about alienating the family. What is the best way to go about it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Reese
title: Like Riding a Tilt-a-Whirl Manned by a Sadist
description: In his dizzying new novel, “My Annihilation,” Fuminori Nakamura destabilizes the reader at every turn.
content: MY ANNIHILATION, by Fuminori Nakamura | Translated by Sam Bett | 254 pp. Soho Crime. $25.95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard, Emily Flitter and Anupreeta Das
title: Buy GameStop, Fight Injustice. Just Don’t Sell.
description: One year in the trenches of the meme stock revolution.
content: It has been a year since Mat Bowen, who was the pastor of a small church in Gibson City, Ill., had the dream — the one where Elon Musk, the head of Tesla, urged him to buy Dogecoin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Cassidy and Ellen Barry
title: Flooding on Nantucket, and High Winds Along the Massachusetts Coast.
description: Some roads were closed and parking lots inundated across Cape Cod and the state’s South Shore. Residents braced for the 9 p.m. high tide.
content: The island of Nantucket was experiencing “significant flooding” on Saturday as the winter storm continued its path through New England, the police reported, and officials advised motorists to avoid several roads in town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Emmanuel Macron Walks a Fine Line on Ukraine
description: The French president, determined to engage with Russia, wants to shape a new European security order from crisis — and win the April election.
content: PARIS — In 2019, Emmanuel Macron invited President Vladimir V. Putin to the French summer presidential residence at Brégançon, declared the need for the reinvention of “an architecture of security” between the European Union and Russia, and later pronounced that NATO had undergone a “brain death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Shane Goldmacher
title: Democrats Decried Dark Money. Then They Won With It in 2020.
description: A New York Times analysis reveals how the left outdid the right at raising and spending millions from undisclosed donors to defeat Donald Trump and win power in Washington.
content: For much of the last decade, Democrats complained — with a mix of indignation, frustration and envy — that Republicans and their allies were spending hundreds of millions of difficult-to-trace dollars to influence politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: 50 Years on, Bloody Sunday’s Wounds Are Still Felt
description: A half-century after the killings in Northern Ireland, symbols of division and hostility still hold their potency.
content: The events themselves took a matter of minutes to unfold in a paroxysm of one-sided gunfire that snuffed out more than a dozen lives, each one of them a new martyr in Northern Ireland’s somber annals of loss. But the effort to unravel what happened in those brief moments — to parse the antecedents and the outcomes, to trace the lines of command on the grisly day that became known as Bloody Sunday — devoured years of costly inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri, Troy Closson and Andrés R. Martínez
title: The storm slammed Long Island, with more to come in coastal New England.
description: People in New England were bracing for more snow and near-hurricane winds. More than 115,000 households were without power in Massachusetts.
content: A powerful winter storm that the National Weather Service classified as a “bomb cyclone” began pummeling eastern Massachusetts on Saturday, dropping as much as a foot of snow from Long Island to New England, where people were bracing for flooding, more snow and near-hurricane strength winds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Rhapsody for a Boy in Blue
description: He should have been the future of policing in New York.
content: We don’t hear much about good cops these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Grabowski
title: The New Wave of Holocaust Revisionism
description: Holocaust distortion is a  threat to memory.
content: WARSAW — The earth outside the tiny village of Treblinka, in eastern Poland, still bears traces of the death camp the Nazis built there in 1942. Close to 925,000 Jews were slaughtered at Treblinka, making it the second-largest Jewish killing field in the world after Auschwitz. On a sad, wet day in November, I wandered close to where Germans had burned the bodies of those murdered in the gas chambers nearby. At my feet on the damp ground, among the pebbles, I saw tiny white specks. They were small pieces of bones that still rise to the surface of the tainted earth of Treblinka after the rain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: How Covid Got Gish Jen Thinking About China
description: The author of nine books was born in America to Chinese immigrants, and she felt the country’s pull as she put together her new story collection, “Thank You, Mr. Nixon.”
content: Gish Jen’s fans can take some solace when they finish one of her books: The characters might reappear in the next one they read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Two Long Island nurses made more than $1.5 million in a fake vaccine card scheme, prosecutors say.
description: The nurses sold fake vaccination cards and entered false information into New York’s immunization database.
content: Two nurses on Long Island are accused of collecting more than $1.5 million by selling forged Covid-19 vaccination cards, according to the Suffolk County district attorney’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Here’s what makes a storm a blizzard.
description: The National Weather Service defines a blizzard by three criteria: blowing or falling snow, winds of at least 35 miles per hour, and visibility of a quarter-mile or less for at least three hours.
content: As a powerful storm moved up the East Coast on Friday, the National Weather Service issued several blizzard warnings, predicted blizzard conditions and even warned that parts of New England could experience a “historical blizzard.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Phyllis Oakley, Female Pioneer at the State Department, Dies at 87
description: She had to quit the foreign service to marry. But she was reinstated 16 years later, when female employees challenged the department’s sexist traditions, and she thrived.
content: Phyllis Oakley, whose 25-year diplomatic career in the State Department almost didn’t happen because of an unwritten rule that forbade female foreign service officers from marrying, died on Jan. 22 at a hospital in Washington. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Mechling
title: Everyone Has Left the Chat
description: Group texts became a social lifeline early in the pandemic. But all conversations must eventually come to an end.
content: It wasn’t until the outset of the pandemic that Sarah O’Dell fully awakened to the allure of the group chat. Stuck at home in Redding, Conn., with her husband and two children, she came to see how a nonstop conversation on her phone could provide welcome distraction, exchange of information and social support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa and Audra D. S. Burch
title: Black Women in Law Feel Pride and Frustration Ahead of Court Nominee
description: As Biden prepares to nominate the first Black woman to the nation’s highest court, members of this small, elite group are watching with complicated emotions.
content: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Laziness, Sleuthing and Surfing
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: There’s a character in the latest Louise Erdrich novel who keeps two piles of books by her bed. One pile is called the “Hard Stack,” and the other is called the “Lazy Stack.” The Hard Stack contains books about species loss, antibiotic resistance and viruses. The Lazy Stack contains Gothic novels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Sundance Canceled? Don’t Tell These Partygoers.
description: The film festival went virtual again this year. But that didn’t stop some veteran attendees from having a good time in Park City anyway.
content: When the Sundance Film Festival announced that it was canceling all in-person events because of the pandemic two weeks before it began, festival goers could be forgiven for thinking the party was over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Officials Charge Man Who Said He Was ‘Coming for’ Biden
description: A Kansas man also described members of the Secret Service as “agents of darkness” and threatened one agent with a bullet, according to court records.
content: A Kansas man who told a Secret Service agent he was “coming for” President Biden was charged on Friday with making threats against the president, according to federal court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Nocera
title: How Cookie Banners Backfired
description: An extensive digital privacy law aimed to give internet users more control over their data. Instead, experts say, it’s created “almost a useless exercise.”
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel, Jenny Vrentas and Kevin Draper
title: Speculation About Tom Brady’s Retirement Intensifies
description: An ESPN report sent observers scrambling on Saturday, but neither Brady’s agent, his team nor the N.F.L. could confirm that the Buccaneers quarterback had made a decision about his football career.
content: Questions about Tom Brady’s future intensified on Saturday after reports surfaced that he planned to retire after 22 seasons in the N.F.L. His agent declined to put a timetable on such a decision, or to confirm the veracity of the reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Powerful Winter Storm Brings Whipping Winds and Heavy Snow to the Northeast
description: Forecasters called it a “bomb cyclone.” Boston got almost two feet of snow, tying a single-day record.
content: Packing raking winds, blinding snows and piercing cold, a powerful, fast-moving winter storm roared up the East Coast on Saturday, bringing power outages, disrupted travel and general misery to millions of residents from the Carolinas to Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: Orcas Are Able to Kill and Eat Blue Whales, Scientists Confirm
description: Recordings in seas off Australia proved that the predatory prowess of killer whales is inescapable, even for the adults of the largest species that ever lived.
content: In March 2019, scientists studying whales near Southwestern Australia stumbled upon a supersize spectacle that few had seen before — a pod of orcas viciously attacking a blue whale.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Shane Goldmacher
title: What We Learned About ‘Dark Money’
description: We recently spent two months investigating the flow of so-called dark money in 2020 to try to shed light on how vast sums of hard-to-trace cash influence politics and policy.

author: By Axel Boada and Nailah Morgan
title: Powerful Winter Storm Slams the East Coast
description: The snowstorm dropped up to 16 inches of snow in some parts of the Northeast. Tens of thousands of people were without power in some regions and thousands of flights were canceled.
content: The snowstorm dropped up to 16 inches of snow in some parts of the Northeast. Tens of thousands of people were without power in some regions and thousands of flights were canceled.

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Brent McDonald, Andriy Dubchak and Dmitriy Khavin
title: ‘My Soul Is Crying’: Ukrainians Remember a Deadly Rocket Attack
description: Residents in Mariupol, a Ukrainian front-line city rocked by shelling in 2015, mourn the dead as they brace for a potential Russian escalation.

title: Corrections: Jan. 29, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 29, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about school closures in India misspelled the surname of the head of the Population Foundation. She is Poonam Muttreja, not Poonam Mattreja.
source.name: The New York Times
